sentence: Stocks have reversed earlier losses and are now posting slim gains, led by strength in financial, energy and homebuilder stocks following upbeat earnings from Dow component Home Depot ( HD ).
The Dow Jones Industrials Average is again flirting with yesterday's record high after Carl Icahn backpedaled from his rally-busting remarks yesterday about a stock market correction.
Shares also are picking up support on speculation the European Central Bank is considering a quantitative easing program to further stimulate the European economy.

Today's economic data did little to move the market in either direction with the Bureau of Labor Statistics reporting its Employment Cost Index declined 0.1% from the prior quarter to a seasonally adjusted 0.4% rise during Q3.
Economists polled by MarketWatch had been expecting 0.5% growth.
Wages and salaries rose 0.3% during the quarter while benefits picked up by 0.7%, the bureau said, while compensation costs over the past 12 months was unchanged at 1.9% growth.

European markets were unable to climb out of negative territory with losses resulting from early weakness in U.S. markets and a downward revision to global growth forecasts by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
Crude oil was down $0.17 to $92.82 per barrel.
Natural gas was unchanged at $3.66 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $2.30 to $1,274.70 an ounce, while silver was down $0.01 to $20.35 an ounce.
Copper was up $0.01 to $3.17 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was up 0.03% to $33.63 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 0.61% to $17.81.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was up 0.12% to 23.74 while SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.19% to $123.13.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.23% to $19.62.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

(+) SPEX (+54.24%) Spherix's CompuFill LLC subsidiary has entered into a settlement and license agreement with a leading technology company.
(+) HZNP (+33.11%) Entered into note purchase agreements with investors to issue $150 million aggregate principle and agreed to buy the U.S. rights for Pozen Inc VIMOVO delayed-release tablets.

(+) EQU (+9.7%) Confirms it is in talks for a take-over with an unidentified suitor

(-) BBY (-7.2%) Despite better than expected Q3 earnings, the consumer electronics retailer warned a more competitive environment - especially from Wal-Mart ( WMT ) - could hurt Q4 gross margin as it seeks to compete on price.

(-) LITB (-20.6%) Reports upbeat Q3 earnings but disappoints Wall Street by saying it is expecting Q4 net revenue of between $75.0 mln to $77.0 mln, trailing the consensus estimate by at least $4 mln.
